Question_1.Context: In deep reactive ion etching (DRIE), the aspect ratio of etched features can be limited due to the difficulty of reactive ions and free radicals diffusing into the etched areas as the etch depth increases.
Question_1.Question: What is the main challenge in achieving high aspect ratios in microscale trenches or holes using DRIE?
Question_1.B: The diffusion of reactive ions and free radicals becomes progressively difficult
Question_1.C: The chemical reactions are too slow
Question_1.D: The etch masks are not durable enough
Question_1.Source: During deep reactive ion etching (DRIE), microscale etch masks with small opening such as trenches or holes suffer from limited aspect ratio because diffusion of reactive ions and free radicals become progressively difficult as the number of DRIE cycle increases.

Question_2.Context: In the context of DRIE, the aspect ratio is a critical measure of the etched features, which is often limited for microscale holes due to confinement effects.
Question_2.Question: Why are microscale holes more problematic than trenches in DRIE when it comes to achieving high aspect ratios?
Question_2.A: Because of the higher cost of etching holes
Question_2.B: Due to the chemical properties of silicon
Question_2.D: Due to the simpler geometry of holes
Question_2.Source: For this reason, high aspect ratio structures of microscale trenches or holes are not readily available with standard DRIE recipes and microscale holes are more problematic than trenches due to omni-directional confinement.

Question_3.Context: Optimization of DRIE process parameters, such as bias voltage and inductively coupled plasma power, can promote bottom etching of high aspect ratio hole arrays.
Question_3.Question: Which parameters are considered for optimization to promote the bottom etching of high aspect ratio hole arrays in DRIE?
Question_3.B: Bias voltage and inductively coupled plasma power
Question_3.Source: Bias voltage and inductively coupled plasma power are considered as optimization parameters to promote the bottom etching of the high aspect ratio hole array.

Question_4.Context: In DRIE, the flow rates of gases used for passivation and depassivation steps can be optimized to reduce etch undercut.
Question_4.Question: What gases' flow rates are optimized to reduce the etch undercut in DRIE?
Question_4.Source: In addition, flow rates of octafluorocyclobutane (C4F8) and sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) for passivation and depassivation steps, respectively, are considered as optimization parameters to reduce the etch undercut.

Question_5.Context: The etch selectivity of thermal oxides used as an etch mask in DRIE is an important factor for the etching process.
Question_5.Question: What is the etch selectivity of thermal oxides used as an etch mask in DRIE for high aspect ratio hole array etching?
Question_5.Source: For high aspect ratio hole array etching, thermal oxides with an etch selectivity of 100:1 in a microscale hole array are selected as an etch mask.

Question_6.Context: The DRIE process involves alternating steps of passivation and depassivation, which affect the etch profile of the features being created.
Question_6.Question: What is the purpose of the passivation step in the DRIE process?
Question_6.A: To increase the temperature of the substrate
Question_6.B: To deposit a polymer layer that protects the sidewalls during etching
Question_6.D: To enhance the chemical reaction rate
Question_6.Source: In order to minimize the undercut, octafluorocyclobutane (C4F8) gas flow of passivation step and sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) gas flow of the depassivation step are selected as parameters to optimize.

Question_7.Context: The DRIE process can be optimized by adjusting the flow rate of SF6 gas during the depassivation step to control the etching of the passivation polymer.
Question_7.Question: What effect does decreasing the flow rate of SF6 gas during the depassivation step have in the DRIE process?
Question_7.A: It increases the etching of the passivation polymer
Question_7.B: It decreases the etching of the passivation polymer
Question_7.C: It has no effect on the passivation polymer
Question_7.D: It completely removes the passivation polymer
Question_7.Source: An increase in passivation polymer by C4F8 gas flow and a reduction in etching of the passivation polymer by SF6 gas flow are both effective to improve the sidewall protection at the top of the hole array, hence undercut can be reduced.

Question_8.Context: The aspect ratio of etched features is a significant metric in DRIE, which can be quantified by comparing the top and bottom dimensions of the etched profile.
Question_8.Question: How is the aspect ratio of an etched feature in DRIE quantified?
Question_8.A: By the height of the feature
Question_8.B: By the width of the feature at the top
Question_8.C: By the difference in width between the top and bottom of the feature
Question_8.D: By the ratio of the depth to the width of the feature
Question_8.Source: Because the bottom of the microscale high aspect ratio pattern is narrower than the top, an area reduction ratio (1−(DB/DT)2 or 1−(WB/WT), DT, DB, WT and WB are depicted in Fig. 1) is proposed to quantify the nonuniform etch profiles.

Question_9.Context: In DRIE, the loading effect can influence the etch depth and area reduction ratio of features, particularly in high aspect ratio hole arrays.
Question_9.Question: What is the loading effect in the context of DRIE?
Question_9.A: The effect of temperature on etch rate
Question_9.B: The influence of feature size on chemical reaction rates
Question_9.C: The impact of pattern density on etch uniformity
Question_9.D: The effect of equipment age on etch precision
Question_9.Source: Compared to the hole array having the same diameter as the width of the trench, the trench is more beneficial in both etch depth and area reduction ratio due to the large area to be etched.

Question_10.Context: The DRIE process can be optimized to fabricate microscale hole arrays with high aspect ratios by adjusting various parameters.
Question_10.Question: What is the achieved aspect ratio for a 1.3 μm-diameter hole array after optimizing the DRIE process?
Question_10.Source: As a result of optimization, the aspect ratio of 20 is achieved for 1.3 μm-diameter hole array and etch area reduction at the bottom relative to the top is improved to 21%.
